Complement Clauses - Examples and Features The various types of complement clauses shown in the trees represent the semantic argument structure of the verb as well as its syntactic subcategorization a particular verb allows is determined by as well as . Therefore, there is some degree of cross-linguistic similarity in the types of clausal the verbs subcategorize for.particular verbs select. In each case presented below, you may also be able to think of adjectives which take that type of complement when they are acting as . Some adverbs also select similar complements to form adverbial clauses, as will be seen in
Adverbial Clauses.
Even if your language does not make as many distinctions in the types of complement clauses as asked for here, please key examples in each box using verbs that are as close as possible in meaning to the examples given. This will document how your language expresses a full range of complement clauses.
First, consider verbs which take only a complement clause with or without a complementizer, like:
I believe (that) Jill is my friend. Jill insists (that) she is my friend. I know (that) he likes me.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature sentential_finite_or_transitive to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples (and remove any separate transitive feature).
Next, consider verbs which take either a finite complement clause with or without a complementizer or a sentential complement, like:
I expect that Joe will come to the party. I expect Joe to come to the party.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature sentential_CP_or_-finiteIP to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples.
Now consider verbs which take a direct object as well as either a finite or nonfinite complement, like:
I will persuade Joe that he should come to the party. I will persuade Joe to come to the party.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature sentential_with_object to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples.
Some verbs only take a nonfinite sentential complement, but the subject is when it is different that the main clause subject while it is not expressed when it is coreferent with the main clause subject, as in:
I want to come to the party. I want Joe to come to the party.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature sentential_-finiteIP_or_transitive to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples (and remove any separate transitive feature).
Some verbs only take a nonfinite sentential complement and the subject must be coreferent with the main clause subject and not expressed, as in:
Joe tried to come to the party. I tried to think of more examples.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature sentential_-finiteIPpro-drop_or_transitive to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples (and remove any separate transitive feature).
Some verbs only take a nonfinite complement, but the complementizer ‘for’ is present when the embedded subject is overt, as in:
Joe would hate for Sue to be at the party. Joe hates to dance. I would like to be appreciated.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature sentential_-finite_or_transitive to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples (and remove any separate transitive feature).
Now consider ‘raising’ verbs, which seem to include all the verbs and verbs. These verbs take either a nonfinite complement or an adjective which has a finite complement with a complementizer or a nonfinite complement. The main verb does not have its own subject, so the subject position is filled by the subject of the nonfinite complement, as in 15, 17-18, or by the dummy it (in some languages) when the complement clause is finite, as in 16 and 19:
John seemed to like the tortillas. It seems likely that Joe will come. Joe is likely to come. The weather is certain to change soon. It is certain that the weather will change soon.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature sentential_raising_or_perception to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples which are perception verbs (and remove the separate perception feature. Add the feature sentential_raising_or_copular to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples which are copular verbs, and remove the separate copular feature. In the examples with adjectives, it is really the adjective that is acting as the predicate that selects the complement clause. Therefore, add the feature sentential_A to their lexical entries.
Causatives made up of two clauses have an object that also acts as the subject of the complement clause. That complement clause is always nonfinite, but does not need the nonfinite marker with some verbs, as in 20, while it is required with others, as in 21:
My mother made me clean my room. The other girl caused us to break up.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature causative_syntax to the lexical entries for the main verbs in the examples.
Finally, consider direct and indirect complements of verbs of speaking. Direct quotations, such as in 22, can be just about any sentence or fragment.
Indirect quotations, as in 23-25, are more restricted. Some speech verbs take a finite sentence complement with or without a complementizer, and an optional prepositional or postpositional phrase to express the hearer, as in 23, and some require the hearer to be expressed as an object plus either a finite sentential complement or a nonfinite sentential complement in which the subject must be coreferent with the main clause subject and not expressed, as in 24-25:
Sue said, “I will come to your house tomorrow.” Sue said (to me) that she would come here tomorrow. Sue told me that she would come here tomorrow. Sue told me to come here tomorrow.
Key how similar examples would be expressed in your language here:
Add the feature speech_PP_or_transitive to the lexical entries for the speech verbs that are like said and can take an optional PP (and remove any separate transitive feature). For those speech verbs that express the hearer as an object, like told, add the feature speech_DP_or_transitive (and remove any separate transitive feature). For those speech verbs that express the hearer as an object, but ask a question, like ask, add the feature speech_DPwh_or_transitive (and remove any separate transitive feature).
Your language may also have other restrictions on embedded clauses, such as the embedded verb being in the subjunctive mood or in the perfective aspect.
